docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision B Service of subpoenas addressed to persons in prison [ss 66–74]

heading.title: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS ACT 1992 (CTH)
PART 4 SERVICE OF PROCESS OF TRIBUNALS [ss 47–80]
DIVISION 3 SERVICE OF SUBPOENAS IN THE PERFORMANCE OF ADJUDICATIVE FUNCTIONS [ss 56–74]
Subdivision B Service of subpoenas addressed to persons in prison [ss 66–74]

leg:info.leg:officialname: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS ACT 1992 (CTH)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 4 SERVICE OF PROCESS OF TRIBUNALS [ss 47–80]
DIVISION 3 SERVICE OF SUBPOENAS IN THE PERFORMANCE OF ADJUDICATIVE FUNCTIONS [ss 56–74]
Subdivision B Service of subpoenas addressed to persons in prison [ss 66–74]

leg:heading.title: Service of subpoenas addressed to persons in prison [ss 66–74]

p.text: This Subdivision applies to a subpoena that:
has been issued by a tribunal in connection with the performance of an adjudicative function by the tribunal; and
is addressed to a person (in this Subdivision called the prisoner) who is in prison in a State other than the place of issue and who is required to:
attend before the tribunal for the purpose of complying with the subpoena; or
give oral evidence, by audio link or audiovisual link, to the tribunal.
[s 66 am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[16], effective 7 September 2009]

A court of a State in which a subpoena is issued may order that the prisoner be produced at the time and place specified in the subpoena as the time and place at which compliance with the subpoena is required.
The court may make an order only if it is satisfied that:
the giving of the evidence that the prisoner is likely to give, or the production of a document or thing specified in the subpoena, is necessary in the interests of justice; and
there will be enough time:
for compliance with the order; and
to permit the making of applications under sectionsÂ 71 and 72 .
Before making an order the court may:
require the person (if any) at whose request the subpoena was issued to give such security as the court specifies for ensuring compliance with any obligations under section 73 ; and
stay the proceeding for the making of the order until the security is given.
An order:
may be made subject to specified conditions; and
must be addressed to the custodian of the prisoner.
In this section:
means:
in any case—a person who:
is a magistrate or a judge; and
is a member of, or constitutes, the tribunal that issued the subpoena; or
if the subject matter of the proceeding to which the subpoena relates has a monetary value or concerns a claim for payment of money:
the court that would have jurisdiction to the extent of that monetary value or the amount claimed; or
where there is more than one such court—the court of more limited jurisdiction; or
if the subject matter of the proceeding does not have a monetary value and does not concern a claim for payment of money—a judge of any court, or a magistrate, of the place of issue of the subpoena.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,540] s 68 Service of order for production

p.text: Subject to any conditions specified under paragraph 67(4)(a) , the order for production and the subpoena, or a copy of both the order and the subpoena, must be served on the custodian of the prisoner, together with a copy, or a further copy, of both the order and the subpoena for service on the prisoner.
Service of the order for production and subpoena must be effected in the same way as service of a subpoena in the place of issue.
Service of the order for production and subpoena is effective only if the subpoena contains an address for service of the person (if any) at whose request the subpoena was issued.
The custodian, or, if more than one person is the custodian of the prisoner, any such custodian, must comply with the order for production even if that custodian:
is not the person named in the order as the custodian of the prisoner; or
is not the custodian who was served with the order for production and subpoena.
As soon as practicable after receiving the order for production and subpoena, the custodian must serve a copy of the order and a copy of the subpoena on the prisoner.
If:
the copies are so served; and
the prisoner is released from prison at a time sufficiently prior to the date for compliance with the subpoena to make compliance with the subpoena reasonably practicable;
then:
the prisoner:
is taken to have been served with the subpoena under section 58 ; and
subject to paragraph 70(2)(b) , is required to comply with the subpoena; and
sectionsÂ 63 , 64 and 65 apply in relation to the subpoena as if it has been issued under Subdivision A of this Division; and
section 64 so applies as if the subpoena had been served on the day of release.
The custodian need not comply with the order for production if the person to whom the subpoena is addressed is released from prison before the time for compliance.
Service of the subpoena is effective only if copies of such notices as are prescribed are attached to the subpoena, or copy of the subpoena, served.

Service of the order for production is effective only if, at the time of service or at some other reasonable time before the date for compliance with the order, there are paid or tendered to the custodian the allowances and travelling expenses that would have been required under section 60 to have been paid or tendered to the prisoner if he or she were not in prison.
If, before the time for compliance with the order for production, the person to whom the order relates is released from prison:

the custodian, or a person acting on his or her behalf, must, as soon as practicable, pay or tender to the person the allowances and travelling expenses paid or tendered to the custodian under subsection (1) ; and

the person is not required to comply with the subpoena to which the order relates unless the allowances and travelling expenses were paid or tendered to the person, by the custodian or another person, no later than a reasonable time after the time when the person ceased to be in prison.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,555] s 71 Application for relief from subpoena

p.text: This section applies if the prisoner has a right under the law of the place of issue to apply to the tribunal or a court to set aside or obtain other relief in respect of the subpoena.
Without limiting the ways in which, under the law of the place of issue, the application may be made, it may be made by transmitting the application to the tribunal or court by fax.

Within 24 hours after making the application, the prisoner must cause a copy of the application to be served on the person (if any) at whose request the subpoena was issued at the person's address for service.
For the purposes of calculating the 24 hour period, a day that is:
a Saturday; or
a Sunday; or
a public holiday or bank holiday in the place in which the application is to be served;
does not count.
Without limiting the ways in which, under the law of the place of issue, service may be effected, it may be effected by transmitting the copy to that address by fax.
The tribunal or court may determine the application without a hearing unless the prisoner, or the person (if any) at whose request the subpoena was issued, objects.
For the purposes of determining the application, the tribunal or court may hold a hearing by audio link or audiovisual link.
[subs (7) am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[17]effective 7 September 2009]
A person who is entitled to practise as a barrister, solicitor or both before a court in:
the place of issue of the subpoena; or
another State in which a person is participating in the hearing by audio link or audiovisual link;
has a right of audience before the tribunal or court at the hearing.
[subs (8) am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[18]effective 7 September 2009]
If the tribunal or court sets aside or grants other relief in respect of the subpoena, it is to make any necessary consequential order in respect of the order for production.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,560] s 72 Application for relief from order for production

leg:heading.title: Application for relief from order for production

p.text: Subject to subsection (2) , a court may, on the application of the custodian or the prisoner, set aside or vary the order for production.
The prisoner may only make an application on the ground that compliance with the order would have a substantial detrimental effect on his or her health or safety.
The application must be made to a court that could have made the order.
Without limiting the ways in which, under the law of the place of issue, the application may be made, it may be made by transmitting the application to the court by fax.
Within 24 hours after making the application, the applicant must cause copies of the application to be served:
on the person (if any) at whose request the subpoena was issued at the person's address for service; and
if the applicant is the custodian — on the prisoner; and
if the applicant is the prisoner — on the custodian.
For the purposes of calculating the 24 hour period, a day that is:
a Saturday; or
a Sunday; or
a public holiday or bank holiday in the place in which the application is to be served;
does not count.

Without limiting the ways in which, under the law of the place of issue, service on the person under paragraph (5)(a) may be effected, it may be effected by transmitting the copy to that address by fax.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in determining the application, the court is to take into account:
public safety; and
the prisoner's health and safety.
The court may determine the application without a hearing unless the custodian, the prisoner, or the person (if any) at whose request the subpoena was issued, objects.
For the purposes of determining the application, the court may hold a hearing by audio link or audiovisual link.
[subs (10) am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[19]effective 7 September 2009]
A person who is entitled to practise as a barrister, solicitor or both before a court in:
the place of issue of the subpoena; or
another State in which a person is participating in the hearing by video link or telephone;
has a right of audience before the court at the hearing.
If the court sets aside or varies the order for production, it is to make any necessary consequential order in respect of the subpoena.
In this section:
has the same meaning as in section 67 .
A person who has incurred reasonable expenses as a result of compliance (by that person or another person) with the order for production is entitled to be paid an amount equal to those expenses.
The amount must be paid:
if the court that made the order for production orders a person to pay the amount — by that person; or
in any other case;
if the subpoena was issued at the request of a party to the proceeding to which the subpoena relates by that party; or
if it was issued by the tribunal of its own motion by the State in which the subpoena was issued.
The custodian of the prisoner, and any escort of the prisoner arranged by the custodian, have:
custody of the prisoner; and

while the prisoner is outside the State in which he or she was in prison — the same powers of detention and disposition of the prisoner as the custodian has in relation to the prisoner in that State; and
power to do such things as are necessary to ensure that the prisoner is:
produced in compliance with the order; and
afterwards returned to the prison in which the prisoner was in prison.
Without limiting subsection (1) , the custodian or the escort may, in any State, require that a person in charge of a prison in the State:
receive the prisoner and keep the prisoner in custody for such time as the custodian or the escort requires; and
surrender custody of the prisoner to the custodian or the escort at the time and in the way that the custodian or the escort requires.
The person so required must comply with such requirements as are reasonable.

Subject to any conditions specified in writing by the custodian as conditions to be complied with while the prisoner is outside the State in which he or she was in prison, the law in force in the State that relates to the liability of a person who escapes from lawful custody applies to the prisoner while the prisoner is outside the State for the purposes of compliance with the order for production.
Subsection (4) does not apply to lawful custody in respect of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth.

A person who is serving a sentence of imprisonment in a State is taken to be serving that sentence while the person is outside the State for the purposes of compliance with the order for production so long as the person remains in the custody of the custodian or escort, or in custody arranged by the custodian or escort.
